content:
**"Permanent Total Disablement"** means a disability caused by an Accident as long as the disability lasts for twelve (12) consecutive months from the date of the Accident, prevents you from engaging in any kind of occupation or employment for remuneration or profit and at the expiry of that period our appointed Registered Medical Practitioner confirms that the disability is not going to improve after twelve (12) months.
We will pay the principal sum insured less any other amount paid or payable under the policy as the result of the same Accident.
questions: How is Permanent Total Disablement defined in terms of duration, medical confirmation, and impact on employment, and how does this definition affect the timing and eligibility of claims?
What conditions must be met regarding the duration and medical assessment of a disability for it to qualify as Permanent Total Disablement under the policy?
In the event of Permanent Total Disablement, how does the policy coordinate payments with other benefits payable under the same Accident to determine the final payout?
How does the requirement that the disability prevents any kind of occupation or employment for remuneration or profit influence the assessment of Permanent Total Disablement claims?
What role does the appointed Registered Medical Practitioner play in confirming the permanence of the disability after twelve consecutive months?
If a disability caused by an Accident lasts exactly twelve months but shows signs of improvement, how does this affect the eligibility for Permanent Total Disablement benefits?
How does the policy handle situations where multiple benefits are claimed for the same Accident, specifically regarding the principal sum insured and amounts already paid?
What documentation and medical evidence are implied to be necessary to support a claim for Permanent Total Disablement under this policy?
How does the policy define the starting point for the twelve consecutive months period required to establish Permanent Total Disablement?
In cases where the disability prevents only certain types of employment but not all, how does the policy determine if the Permanent Total Disablement condition is met?
How would the policy treat a scenario where the insured is permanently disabled but continues to engage in unpaid or voluntary work?
What exclusions or general policy conditions might interact with or override the Permanent Total Disablement benefit as defined in this section?
How does the policy address the timing of payments for Permanent Total Disablement in relation to the confirmation by the Registered Medical Practitioner?
If a claim for Permanent Total Disablement is made but the disability improves after twelve months, what impact does this have on the claim payout?
How does the policy ensure that the Permanent Total Disablement benefit is not duplicated when other benefits have been paid for the same Accident?
What is the significance of the phrase 'less any other amount paid or payable under the policy' in the context of Permanent Total Disablement claims?
How might the definition of Permanent Total Disablement affect claims involving partial disabilities or temporary disabilities?
What are the implications for claimants if the appointed Registered Medical Practitioner does not confirm the permanence of the disability after twelve months?
How does the policy treat Permanent Total Disablement claims in cases where the insured was unemployed or not engaged in any occupation at the time of the Accident?
In what ways could the policy's definition of Permanent Total Disablement interact with other policy definitions or exclusions related to accidents and disabilities?
